metadata.title: Preferable phosphate sequestration by nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides modified wheat straw with excellent properties in regeneration

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Chemical Engineering Journal
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /cej
Preferable phosphate sequestration by nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides modified wheat straw with excellent properties in regeneration
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cej.2017.01.043 1385-8947/ 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail address: zhangqr@ysu.edu.cn (Q. Zhang).
Hui Qiu a, Chen Liang a, Jianghua Yu a, Qingrui Zhang b,⇑, Mingxia Song a, Fenghua Chen a,c a Jiangsu Collaborative Innovation Center of Atmospheric Environment and Equipment Technology (CICAEET), School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Nanjing University of Information Science & Technology, 219 Ningliu Road, Nanjing 210044, PR China b State Key Laboratory of Metastable Materials Science and Technology, Yanshan University, Qinhuangdao 066004, PR China cHenan Provincial Key Laboratory of Surface and Interface Science, Zhengzhou University of Light Industry, Zhengzhou, PR China
h i g h l i g h t s
The ‘‘rod-like” biomass-based nanoLa(III) (hydr)oxides was newly prepared. Ws-N-La shows higher preference towards phosphate than commercial HFO-201. The ‘‘needle-like” LaPO4 xH2O is formed during phosphate adsorption. No obvious capacity loss was observed after 10th regeneration.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
Advanced removal of phosphate by low-cost nano-composite with excellent adsorption selectivity and regeneration ability.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 4 November 2016 Received in revised form 11 January 2017 Accepted 12 January 2017 Available online 16 January 2017
Keywords: Wheat straw La(III) (hydr)oxides Phosphate
a b s t r a c t
Enhanced removal of phosphate by biomass-supported adsorbents is an effective and economic method to prevent the accelerated eutrophication in water body. A new nanocomposite Ws-N-La is fabricated for efficient phosphate removal by immobilizing ‘‘rod-like” nano-sized La(III) (hydr)oxides within a quaternary-aminated wheat straw (Ws-N). It exhibits higher adsorption capacity towards phosphate than the commercial IRA-900 or HFO-201 even at higher competing anions levels. The pH result indicated that the Ws-N-La would effectively sequestrate phosphate over a wide pH range between 3.0 and 7.0 without significant La(III) leaching. Ten cycles of adsorption-desorption experiments reveals that no significant capacity loss is observed, indicating excellent stability and repeated use property than any other La(III)-based adsorbents. The results of TEM, XRD and XPS analysis demonstrated that the formation of
Needle-like Regeneration
‘‘needle-like” lanthanum phosphate nanoparticle is the dominant pathway for the specific adsorption of phosphate by nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides. All the results suggested that the biomass-supported nanocomposite Ws-N-La can serve as a promising adsorbent for preferable phosphate removal in realistic application.
2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Phosphorus (P) is usually considered to be the limiting nutrient with respect to the eutrophication of natural water bodies such as rivers, lakes and marines [1]. Excess phosphorus in surface waters can cause serious outbreaks of algal bloom, and reduce biodiversity in aquatic ecosystems [2]. Studies revealed that the acceptable total phosphorus concentrations in lake should not exceed 0.03 mg/L [3]. Hence, there is an urgent need to control the level of phosphate in discharged wastewater before its release into the environment. In addition, as a kind of non-renewable resource, phosphate may be depleted in 50–100 years due to the world growing demands. In this regard, it is also important to recover phosphate from contaminated waters [4,5].
Traditionally, chemical precipitation, biological removal, electrochemical treatment, and ion exchange are commonly applied techniques for phosphate-removing from contaminated water [6–8]. However, the high costs and strict regulated standard for phosphate discharge are still severe challenges. To be specific, in China the maximum allowable phosphate is set as 0.5 mg P/L nowadays for municipal wastewater treatment plant [9], replacing the previous standard of 1.0 mg P/L. Furthermore, it’s difficult to recovery and utilization of trace phosphate using the conventional technologies.
Nowadays, adsorption is generally considered to be an attractive alternative because of its simple operation, low cost, and potential for phosphate recovery from contaminated water [10– 13]. Various transitional metallic oxides are proved to be efficient adsorbents for phosphate retentions by their strong inner-sphere complexation, for example, zirconium oxides and iron oxides, aluminum oxides [14–16]. However, the adsorption capacity of them would inherently not be satisfying and still need improving. In recent years, lanthanum oxides are confirmed to possess ultrahigh activity for phosphate sequestration, approximately ten times greater than that of famous aluminum oxides powder according to previous studies [16,17]. More importantly, it could provide a great quantity of coordination sites and exhibit specific affinity toward phosphate even at trace levels. As one of the rare earth elements, Lanthanum has taken advantages of non-toxic and environmentally compatible, as well as the low cost due to the large reserves in the earth’s crust [18].
Unfortunately, metallic oxides powder seems to be inappropriate for practical application directly due to its poor mechanical strength, the difficulty in separation directly from water and recycle use [19,20]. Therefore, a growing attention are paid to La(III)based hybrid materials with larger particle size. As a new generation adsorbent for water treatment, such hybrid martials could combine the specific affinity of La(III) (hydr)oxides towards phosphate as well as the excellent hydraulic and mechanic performance by the host materials. Some researches about La-modified materials have been reported, such as La-loaded clay, and La-doped mesoporous hollow silica sphere [17,21].
However, most of the host materials have no adsorption sites or functional groups coexisted on the inner surface of them, which playing the role just as ‘‘supporters”, such as mesoporous silicates (MCM-41 or SBA-15) [21,22]. In the latest research, porous polystyrene network was indicated to be an ideal alternative to other
host materials due to the Donnan membrane effect caused by the immobilized charged groups bound to the polymeric phase, where phosphate ions could be easily pre-concentrated and get enhanced permeation prior to preferable sequestration by La(III) (hydr)oxides [23]. In particular, the exhausted hybrid adsorbent can be readily regenerated with alkaline solution for several continuous repeated use without significant capacity loss. Thus, the selection of an appropriate host material is of great significance for La(III) (hydr)oxides immobilization.
Based on that, the natural agricultural byproduct – straw biomass, which found to possess a large amount of reactive hydroxyl groups that could be easily grafted with various charged functional groups, represents a potential alternative as an excellent host material [24–27]. Comparatively, the synthesis of polystyrene network requires a lot of toxic chemical reagents, such as nitrobenzene, chloromethyl ether and styrene, and usually generates a variety of toxic organic intermediates, leading to serious secondary pollution. The reuse of natural wheat straw could not only minify the recontamination in the fabrication, but also facilitate the comprehensive utilization of agricultural residues. Currently, several methods for modification of biomass have been investigated. The positively ammonium groups were introduced into rice hull after reaction with epichlorohydrin and triethylamine using pyridine as catalyst, and the resulting ion exchanger was applied to adsorb nitrate in water. Another biomass-based adsorbent modified by quaternary ammonium groups showed satisfied properties towards phosphate, using ethlenediamine (EDA) as cross-linking agent [28,29]. Meanwhile, a series of sewages with strong excitant smell would be produced when using pyridine as catalyst or EDA as cross-linking agent in the preparation. Considering this, a simplified aminated modification by using epichlorohydrin and triethylamine only would be chosen to avoid recontamination in the modification of Ws.
In present research, a biomass-supported composite Ws-N-La is prepared by anchoring nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides onto an agricultural residue – wheat straw (Ws), which covalently grafted of quaternary ammonium groups after reacting with epichlorohydrin and triethylamine. The basic morphology and physicochemical properties of the new composite are characterized, and the phosphate removal performance is examined by batch sorption experiments. Binary NaOH-NaCl solution is applied to regenerate the saturated adsorbent and recovery phosphate in order to evaluate the practical performance of the novel developed adsorbent. Moreover, the underlying mechanism of phosphate adsorption by the nanocomposite is further explored by the X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). This study provides an effective way for comprehensive utilization of biomass resources, and provides a reliable theoretical and technical support for the removal and recovery of phosphate in contaminated waters.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals
sections.text:
All of the reagents used in the study are of analytical grade. Sodium dihydrogen phosphate (NaH2PO4) was employed as the
source of phosphorus for the adsorption experiments. The stock solutions of phosphate were prepared at concentration of 1000 mg P/L. Lanthanum(III) nitrate hexahydrate (La(NO3)3 6H2O) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All the solutions were prepared by deionized water (18.2 MX cm). Wheat straw (Ws) was obtained from Lianyungang, Jiangsu, China. It was divided into irregular particles with a diameter of 0.5– 1.0 mm. After divided into irregular particles with a diameter of 0.5–1.0 mm, the Ws particles were subjected with NaOH solution (0.1 M) to remove the residual impurities, followed by rinsing with deionized water until neutral pH, then washed by 50% ethanol solution and dried in an oven at 313 K for 12 h for stand-by. Other chemicals were provided by Shanghai Reagent station (Shanghai, China). Other chemicals such as LaPO4 xH2O, La(OH)3 and La2O3 were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co., USA.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of materials
sections.text: In order to prepare the functionalized wheat straw carrier, 5 g of dried Ws was mixed with 100 mL of N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) at ambient temperature for 1 h; and then added 25 mL epichlorohydrin to the mixture as etherification agent and stirred for 2 h at 358 K, followed by a slow addition of triethylamine to graft quaternary ammonium groups on Ws. The solution was allowed to stir for 3 h at 358 K and then filtered, and the reaction product was washed with 1 L of NaOH (0.1 M), 1 L of HCl (0.1 M), and 1 L of 50% ethanol solution and then dried in an oven at 313 K for 12 h to obtain the biomass-based anion-exchanger WsN. To further synthesize the nano-composite, 60 g La(NO3)3 6H2O was dissolved in 100 mL deionized water containing 20% (v/v) ethanol. The Ws-N (5 g) was stirred in the solution for 6 h. Then the solution was filtered to gain the La(III)-loaded Ws-N followed by vacuum-desiccation at 323 K. The dried product was immersed into 100 mL of 0.1 M NaOH solution with continuous stirring at 298 K for 6 h. The preloaded La(III) was then in situ precipitated as La(III) (hydr)oxides onto the surface of the host Ws-N. To further transform the OH-type material to Cl-type, the materials was immersed into 250 mL of NaCl (0.5 M) solution for 4 times, then washed with deionized water until neutral pH and dried at 313 K for 24 h to obtained the biomass-supported nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides Ws-N-La. Fabrication of the nano-composite Ws-N-La was schematically illustrated in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 2.3. Batch experiments
sections.text:
A series of batch adsorption experiments were conducted to investigate the phosphate adsorption performances of the prepared samples. Adsorption isotherms for phosphate were performed as follows: 0.05 g of adsorbent was added into 100 mL of phosphate solutions with different initial concentrations varied from 5.0 to 80.0 mg P/L containing 0.01 M NaNO3 as the background electrolyte. The sealed bottles were then shaken at 150 rpm for 24 h at 298 K. Dilute HNO3 (0.1 M) and NaOH (0.1 M) solutions were used to adjust solution pH at 6.0 ± 0.2 every 4 h throughout the experiment. The effect of pH on phosphate adsorption was conducted at solution pH (2.4–10.9) using appropriate amounts of either NaOH or HNO3 solution (0.1 M). The initial phosphate concentration was set as 30.0 mg P/L and the ionic background was 0.01 M NaNO3. To investigate the effect of competitive ions on phosphate adsorption, a certain amount of Na2SO4, NaCl, NaNO3 and NaHCO3 was added to adjust different ionic strength with 5–100 times higher than phosphate concentration. In adsorption kinetic experiments, 0.25 g of the adsorbent was added into 500 mL of phosphate solution with an initial concentration of 30.0 mg P/L containing 0.01 M NaNO3 as the background electrolyte. 1 mL of the solution was taken out of the bottle at various
time intervals for analysis. Preliminary kinetic experiments confirmed that 8 h was sufficient to reach the adsorption equilibrium. To evaluate the reusability of Ws-N-La, 0.10 g sample was added into 100 mL phosphate solution (20 mg P/L) for 24 h at 333 K for adsorption-desorption test for 10 cycles and binary NaOH (5%, 10%, 15%) + NaCl (5%) solution was used as regenerant. Note that the composite Ws-N-La was washed with deionized water until neutral pH to ensure similar sorption pH condition prior to nextcycle adsorption. The concentration of phosphate in the final solution was analyzed by UV–vis spectrophotometry. All the batch experiments were performed in triplicates.

sections.heading: 2.4. Analysis methods
sections.text: The morphology of the samples was examined by scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi, S-3400 II, Japan) operating at 15 kV. The nanosized La(III) (hydr)oxides impregnated on the Ws-N was observed with transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL, JEM-2100 HR, Japan). The powder X-ray diffraction analysis instrument (XRD, XTRA, Switzerland) with Cu Ka radiation (40 kV, 25 mA) was applied to detect the crystallographic phases of loaded La(III) (hydr)oxides and the phase-changes after adsorption and regeneration. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis was performed on a PHI 5000 Versaprobe system, using monochromatic Al Ka anode radiation as the excitation source. All binding energies (BE) were referenced to the C1s peak at 284.6 eV, and the experimental data were fitted with XPSPEAK41 for analysis. The amount of La(III) loaded within Ws-N-La and La(III) leaching from Ws-N-La in solution was determined by inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Perkin Elmer Model Optima 5300DV, USA) after acid digestion by nitric–perchloric acid solution. Phosphate concentration was measured by molybdenum blue spectrophotometric method with a UV–vis spectrometer (T6, PGENERAL, China). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were carried out at 77 K to measure the specific surface area and pore volume of the samples by a Micromeritics ASAP-2010C Instrument (Norcross, GA). Total nitrogen content of the samples was detected through a Perker-Elmer Elemental analyzer CHNS/O (model 2400II).

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of the materials
sections.text:
The resultant composite Ws-N-La is present as thin flake particles in yellow color, which is a little darker than the original wheat straw (Ws). The SEM images (Fig. 2a) shows that some distinct grooves and eyelets can be clearly seen on the external surface of Ws. When La(III) encapsulated, the number of grooves increases apparently and the surface morphology becomes much coarser (Fig. 2b), indicating a larger specific surface areas of new prepared Ws-N-La. Compared to the TEM image of Ws-N (Fig. S1), the La(III) nanoparticles (NPs) are uniformly dispersed as rod-like shape inside the host matrix of Ws-N-La (Fig. 2c), with sizes of about 10–20 nm in length and 10 nm in width [30,31].
Fig. 3 shows that the wide-angle XRD patterns of the sample Ws, Ws-N and Ws-N-La. The broad peak at 2h values of 23 is the characteristic peak of Ws. After La(III) NPs impregnated, the reflections present several peaks which resemble the crystalline structure of compound La(OH)3 (Fig. S2), implying the formation of La(III) (hydr)oxides species. The BET specific surface areas are increased from 3.27 m2/g to 78.76 m2/g for Ws and Ws-N-La, respectively (Table 1). The larger BET data of Ws-N-La might result from the encapsulated nano-sized La(III) (hydr)oxides, which can provide a higher surface area with more active adsorption sites.
The La(III) content is approximately 15.10% in mass, measured by ICP after acidic digestion. The above results further confirm that nanosized La(III) are successfully doped into the biomass matrix.
The results of elemental analysis are listed in Table S1. The nitrogen contents increase from 0.17% (Ws) to 1.63% (Ws-N), which suggests that quaternary ammonium groups have successfully grafted on the matrix of original Ws. For the composite WsN-La, the value has declined to 0.64% (Ws-N-La), probably due to the formation of a higher density by nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides immobilization. The total exchange capacity (TEC) is calculated from the nitrogen content incorporated into the composite based on the equation TEC (mEq g 1) = N%/1.4 [24]. The TEC value of Ws-N-La is obtained to be 0.46 mEq g 1, lower than that of Ws-N (1.16 mEq g 1). Besides, the La leaching at varying pH is detected to examine the stability of Ws-N-La as shown in Fig. S3. After being immersed for 48 h, La leaching increases substantially when the pH value is lower than 3.0. Only 3.9 wt% of the total La is leaching
into solution at pH = 3.0, however, it reached 54 wt% when pH value decline to 1.9. Therefore, the nano-composite Ws-N-La exhibits much better performance at pH > 3. Actually, most of the micropolluted water containing phosphate could satisfy such conditions.

sections.heading: 3.2. Comparison of three samples for phosphate removal
sections.text: Fig. 4 compares the adsorption behavior of phosphate onto the nano-composite Ws-N-La and the references Ws-N and Ws at 298 K. The results illustrate that the original Ws has negligible adsorption capacity for phosphate, which suggests that the –OH groups onto Ws cannot be utilized as active adsorption sites. But for anion exchanger Ws-N, the quaternary ammonium groups modification induces to attach the improving adsorption capability toward phosphate ions. The maximum adsorption capacity is approached to 19.6 mg P/g, calculated by Langmuir isotherm model. Comparatively, the composite Ws-N-La exhibits the maximum adsorption amounts of about 67.1 mg P/g. The superior performance of Ws-N-La can be attributed to its specific bifunctional structure, i.e. the nonspecific adsorption caused by immobilized quaternary ammonium groups which could provided Donnan membrane enrichment of phosphate ions, and the specific adsorption toward phosphate exerted by the impregnated nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides. The adsorption mechanism will be further discussed in subsequent section.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of solution pH
sections.text:
The effect of solution pH on phosphate uptake by Ws-N-La was examined and present in Fig. 5. The composite Ws-N-La exhibits pH-dependent adsorption for phosphate with optimum pH ranging from 2.4 to 6.5 (>50.0 mg P/g). At higher pH value, the adsorption capacity dropped gradually to 20.0 mg P/g when pH increase to 10.9. Obviously, the increasing concentration of –OH in alkaline
solution will greatly compete for the active sorption sites with phosphate ions, resulting in a significant decrease in phosphate adsorption. In addition, the point of zero charge (pHzpc) of Ws-NLa is 10.7 measured by potentiometric titration. The new material would become negatively charged when solution pH is larger than 10.7, which could have the same charge as phosphate ions. Thus, the Donnan co-ion exclusion or electrostatic repulsive forces would be dominated in adsorption, which is favorable for the loaded phosphate desorption [32]. That explains the dramatic decrease of phosphate uptake when the pH value is approaching 10.7. At acidic pH surroundings (2.4–7.0), the negatively charged H2PO4– is the dominated species as shown in Fig. S4, meanwhile, Ws-N-La is positively charged. The phosphate ions can be selectively trapped by La(III) nanoparticle through the formation of inner-sphere complexes. Based on the results of pH effect and La leaching, the new Ws-N-La would effectively sequestrate phosphate over a wide pH range between 3.0 and 7.0, alkaline pH is not favorable for phosphate sequestration.

sections.heading: 3.4. Effect of competing anions
sections.text:
The co-exist anions, such as SO42 , Cl , NO3 , and HCO3 , which commonly occurring in natural waters or wastewater, are supposed to compete with phosphate ions for the active sites of adsorbents. The effects of the above anions on phosphate adsorption by Ws-N-La are further evaluated in Fig. 6a. The synthetic biomass anion exchanger Ws-N and the commercial anion exchange resin IRA-900 are also employed for references. Besides, another nanocomposite Ws-N-Zr, which was developed by our previous study, is also involved here for comparison [33].
An observable capacity loss (5–30%) was obtained for Ws-N-La in competitive background. But for Ws-N and IRA-900, the decreased value for phosphate was up to 80–95% (Fig. 6b). The new Ws-N-La include the bifunctional active sites for phosphate removal as we mentioned above. The so-called Donnan membrane effects for Ws-N-La are originated from the fixed quaternary ammonium functional groups, which are highly positive-charged. It can construct a strong electrostatic surrounding within matrix nanoporous region. Therefore, the negative-charged ions (e.g. phosphate or sulfate) will be enhanced diffusion and rapid enrichment, such process is non-specific or non-selective adsorption [32]. In the system of single phosphate adsorption (without competitive ions), the target phosphate ions will be adsorbed by both fixed ammonium groups and immobilized nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides, the quaternary ammonium will promote the possibility for nanoLa(III) (hydr)oxides and target phosphates. By contrast, when the competitive ions were added, the Donnan membrane enrichment
will be available for the phosphate as well as competitive SO42 or Cl ions etc. Thus, the competitive SO42 or Cl ions will also be attracted into the adsorbent phase, which occupy most sorption sites of quaternary ammonium groups. As a result, sorption performance would be weaken by comparing to the single phosphate system. But the immobilized nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides can exert strong inner-sphere complexation, which will only adsorb phosphate ions rather than competitive ions. In a word, the fixedcharged ammonium groups will exert the Donnan membrane effects, which will offer the enrichment of phosphate ions. It can promote the possibility or accessibility toward phosphate and nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides. Considering the non-specific property, it is not an important role for phosphate adsorption. The selectivity will be mainly provided by nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides rather than ammonium groups.
As for Ws-N-Zr, although the preferential phosphate adsorption can also be achieved in the presence of competitive ions, the total amount of adsorption was far lower than that of Ws-N-La (Fig. 6b). In addition, a commercially available phosphate sorbent HFO-201 which has a similar structure as HAIX was also involved here for comparison [13,32]. According to the previous reports, the adsorption capacity of phosphate by HFO-201 is about 34 mg P/g with initial concentration of 30.0 mg P/L, while that for Ws-N-La is 53 mg P/g at same conditions. Furthermore, the adsorption amount decline to no more than 10 mg P/g when coexist anions increasing from 0 to 20 times of phosphate. In contrast, the new Ws-N-La in this work still reveals much higher adsorption capability than HFO-201 under same conditions, which further demonstrate the inherent high activity of nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides towards phosphate.

sections.heading: 3.5. Adsorption kinetics
sections.text:
Fig. 7a presents the plots of phosphate adsorption versus contact time for Ws-N-La in the absence or presence of sulfate ions at high concentration and the host Ws-N and commercial anion ion-exchanger RNA-900 are also employed for comparison. Note that 40 times sulfate/phosphate (mol/mol) ions are selected as the background for screening the possible adsorption from quaternary ammonium groups. Obviously, Ws-N-La exhibits much greater capacity for phosphate sequestration than the referred Ws-N and IRA-900, and the adsorption equilibrium was achieved
within 8 h. While the host Ws-N and commercial IRA-900 shows negligible adsorption by sulfate ions addition, which coincides with the results of competing test. Besides, the intraparticle diffusion model is used to describe the kinetic data. The equation is listed below:
Q t ¼ kit0:5 þ C
where t (min) is reaction time, Qt (mg/g) is the adsorbed amount of phosphate at time t, ki (mg/g min0.5) is diffusion rate constant of any step and C is the intercept for any experiment. As shown in Fig. 7b, the kinetic results of Ws-N-La are well described by the intraparticle diffusion model. Interestingly, the two stage sorption suggests the distinct diffusion pathways prior to adsorption equilibrium. The diffusion rate constant k1 and k2 is 26.44 and 0.67, 32.61 and 1.20 mg/g min0.5 for sulfate absence and presence systems, respectively (Table S2). It can be observed that the diffusion rate constant k2 is much smaller than k1. To be specific, the target phosphate ions are adsorbed onto the exterior surface controlled by film diffusion, so the adsorption rate is fast in the beginning (step 1). Subsequently, phosphate ions are further sequestrated into the interior surface of the new Ws-N-La (step 2) in the intraparticle diffusion process. The diffusion resistance increased when phosphate ions diffused inside the pore of the particle, resulting in the declining of diffusion rate constant ki. Finally, the third part is the final equilibrium stage, where the rates of adsorption and desorption keep equivalent. Note that k2 is much smaller than k1, which can be ascribed to the possible diffusion resistance from the inner nanopore structures.

sections.heading: 3.6. Adsorption – Desorption cycle
sections.text:
Batch adsorption-desorption cycles are carried out to investigate the repeated property of the composited Ws-N-La. Inspiringly, the exhausted Ws-N-La can be readily regenerated using binary NaOH-NaCl (x%-5%) solutions, and the different NaOH concentrations (5 wt%, 10 wt%, 15 wt%) are performed to evaluate the desorbed efficiency at 333 K. Efficient regeneration and repeated use for Ws-N-La by NaOH-NaCl solution with different NaOH concentrations can be performed at least ten cycles, as shown in Fig. 8. After first regeneration, the efficiency of the 2th adsorption is maintained at 94%, as same as the result for first adsorption. Not only that, negligible capacity loss was observed for the first three
adsorption-desorption cycle. Then, the subsequent 4th to 10th cycle results prove that the adsorption efficiency for 10 wt%, 15 wt% NaOH are maintained above 85%, apparently higher and much stable than that for 5 wt%. Therefore, it can be concluded that the preloaded phosphate could be effectively desorbed by regenerating solution with 10% and 15% NaOH systems. Considering the fact of economic costs, the binary NaOH-NaCl solution with 10% NaOH concentration should be selected as the optimal desorption solution for regeneration.

sections.heading: 3.7. Adsorption mechanism
sections.text:
The new biomass-supported nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides with excellent performance toward phosphate is successfully prepared, and the adsorption mechanism for Ws-N-La is further probed using TEM, XRD and XPS investigation. As we known, the bifunctional sites on Ws-N-La are responsible for phosphate sequestration. (1) the quaternary ammonium groups within host matrix, (2) the impregnated nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides. The TEM image (Fig. 2c-d) shows that the rod-like nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides transferred into the needle-like nanocrystallites after phosphate adsorbed, which resembles the morphology of LaPO4 crystals [34]. The needle-like nanocrystallites are approximately 10–20 nm in length and 1– 5 nm in width. It is inferred that a new substance is generated dur-
ing phosphate adsorption. The results can be further verified by the evolution of XRD spectra listed below.
The XRD patterns (Fig. 9) depict the evolution of the crystal state of Ws-N-La during the adsorption-desorption cycle. It can be detected that the phosphate adsorption can induce the crystalline lanthanum phosphate specie formation, and the new emerging reflections can well coincide the patterns of purified LaPO4 xH2O samples. After a complete phosphate desorption, the XRD diffractograms of Ws-N-La are recovered to its original state, which has the similar crystal structure to La(OH)3 (d labels). It is noteworthy that the new formed LaPO4 species within the nanopore surroundings of Ws-N-La are assigned to the low crystalline pattern and then, the alkaline treatment can achieve the transformation of La(III) (hydr)oxides completely with refreshed sorption capability for phosphate removal. Therefore, it is concluded that the conversion between La(III)-(hydr)oxides and LaPO4 xH2O were reversible. In addition, the XRD patterns of the Ws-N-La after regeneration are highly consistent with the original one, suggesting its distinguished stability.
Furthermore, the XPS analysis was also conducted to gain further insight into the possible sorption mechanism. Fig. 10a shows that the binding energy of P 2p onto phosphate loaded Ws-N sample is centered at 131.9 eV, while the P 2p peak of purified NaH2-
PO4 is located at 132.0 eV. The slight band shifts indicate the present non-specific adsorption between the quaternary ammonium and phosphate. Surprisingly, that for phosphate loaded La(III)(hydr)oxides, a remarkable shifts to higher binding energy of P 2p at 132.6 eV are observed, which suggests the present strong sorption affinity for LaPO4 xH2O formation. The XPS study for phosphate-preloaded Ws-N-La in the absence or presence of sulfate is also investigated in Fig. 10b. Considering the bifunctional components and the broaden p 2p peak, the widen P 2p spectrum of Ws-N-La can be divided into two representative peaks (A: phosphate loaded ammonium group; B: the strong LaPO4 species) and the corresponding areas fractions are 41.3% and 58.7% respectively. While the competing sulfate ion additions (sulfate/phos-
phate = 20) can bring about a remarkable fraction variations. The phosphate uptake onto ammonium group was dramatically declines from 41.3% to 7.1%. By comparison, that for La(III) sites (B Peak), the occupation increases from 58.7% to 92.9%, which further verifies the powerful affinity between phosphate and the nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides.
The representative satellite peaks of La 3d5/2 for original Ws-NLa are centered at 834.8 and 838.1 eV (Fig. 10c), respectively. The appearance of doublet satellite peaks at higher energies is often observed in La based hydr(oxides) and is explained as the result of charge transfer from the valence band of the ligand atom to the 4f orbital of the La atom. Observably, phosphate uptake can lead to the apparent variations of the proportion onto La 3d5/2 dou-
a2H2PO4, Ws-N-P and LaPO4 samples; (b) p 2p spectral of the phosphate loadedWsctral of Ws-N-La with phosphate adsorption; (e) La 3d5/2 spectral of Ws-N-La with O4: 40 M/M; Adsorption dose: 0.5 g/L; Temperature: 298 K; pH: 6.0 ± 0.2; T = 24 h.)
ble peaks and a distinct peak shifts to higher binding energy (Fig. 10d), suggesting the new La-complex formation. Thus, the broad peaks can be allocated into double peak groups and the new emerged peaks are attached at 835.4 eV and 839.3 eV, respectively. The large shifts of 0.5 eV and 1.2 eV indicate the present strong affinity and the new formation of LaPO4 species. Note that, the corresponding area fractions of primitive la-OH sites and LaPO4 species are nearly equally. Interestingly, the sulfate addition can bring about a slightly increase in LaPO4 species formation with areas occupation from 50% to 57.5%, which suggests the existing SO42 can enhance the phosphate adsorption relatively. Such phenomenon for phosphate enhancement further demonstrate the realization of strong inner-sphere complexation within LaPO4 species and similar results were also observed in our previous study using zirconium phosphate for phosphate capture [35].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In the present study, a new composite Ws-N-La is fabricated for preferable phosphate adsorption by anchoring nano-La(III) (hydr) oxides within a quaternary-aminated wheat straw (Ws-N). Indicated by TEM image, the La(III) (hydr)oxides are uniformly dispersed as ‘‘rod-like” nanoparticles inside the biomass matrix with sizes of 10–20 nm in length and 10 nm in width. The Ws-N-La exhibits much higher preference toward phosphate than the commercial IRA-900 and HFO-201 when competing anions coexisted at higher levels. Phosphate ions can be effectively captured between pH 3.0–7.0 without significant La(III) leaching through bifunctional adsorption sites of Ws-N-La. Ten cycles of adsorption-desorption experiments shows that no significant capacity loss is observed for 10% NaOH concentration. As demonstrated by TEM, XRD, XPS investigation, such preferable phosphate uptake of Ws-N-La can be attributed to the electrostatic interaction exerted by positively charged quaternary-aminated groups as well as the complexation interaction exerted by impregnated nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides. The newly formed ‘‘needle-like” LaPO4 xH2O is demonstrated to be the dominant pathway for specific adsorption by anchored nanoLa(III) (hydr)oxides. Above all, the resultant Ws-N-La can be acted as a promising adsorbent candidate for efficient preferable removal from contaminated water.

sections.text: Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cej.2017.01.043.

referenceMentions.context: Phosphorus (P) is usually considered to be the limiting nutrient with respect to the eutrophication of natural water bodies such as rivers, lakes and marines [1].
Excess phosphorus in surface waters can cause serious outbreaks of algal bloom, and reduce biodiversity in aquatic ecosystems [2].
In this regard, it is also important to recover phosphate from contaminated waters [4,5].
In this regard, it is also important to recover phosphate from contaminated waters [4,5].

In recent years, lanthanum oxides are confirmed to possess ultrahigh activity for phosphate sequestration, approximately ten times greater than that of famous aluminum oxides powder according to previous studies [16,17].

In recent years, lanthanum oxides are confirmed to possess ultrahigh activity for phosphate sequestration, approximately ten times greater than that of famous aluminum oxides powder according to previous studies [16,17].
As one of the rare earth elements, Lanthanum has taken advantages of non-toxic and environmentally compatible, as well as the low cost due to the large reserves in the earth’s crust [18].

Unfortunately, metallic oxides powder seems to be inappropriate for practical application directly due to its poor mechanical strength, the difficulty in separation directly from water and recycle use [19,20].

Unfortunately, metallic oxides powder seems to be inappropriate for practical application directly due to its poor mechanical strength, the difficulty in separation directly from water and recycle use [19,20].
Some researches about La-modified materials have been reported, such as La-loaded clay, and La-doped mesoporous hollow silica sphere [17,21].
Some researches about La-modified materials have been reported, such as La-loaded clay, and La-doped mesoporous hollow silica sphere [17,21].

However, most of the host materials have no adsorption sites or functional groups coexisted on the inner surface of them, which playing the role just as ‘‘supporters”, such as mesoporous silicates (MCM-41 or SBA-15) [21,22].

However, most of the host materials have no adsorption sites or functional groups coexisted on the inner surface of them, which playing the role just as ‘‘supporters”, such as mesoporous silicates (MCM-41 or SBA-15) [21,22].

In the latest research, porous polystyrene network was indicated to be an ideal alternative to other host materials due to the Donnan membrane effect caused by the immobilized charged groups bound to the polymeric phase, where phosphate ions could be easily pre-concentrated and get enhanced permeation prior to preferable sequestration by La(III) (hydr)oxides [23].
Another biomass-based adsorbent modified by quaternary ammonium groups showed satisfied properties towards phosphate, using ethlenediamine (EDA) as cross-linking agent [28,29].
Another biomass-based adsorbent modified by quaternary ammonium groups showed satisfied properties towards phosphate, using ethlenediamine (EDA) as cross-linking agent [28,29].

Thus, the Donnan co-ion exclusion or electrostatic repulsive forces would be dominated in adsorption, which is favorable for the loaded phosphate desorption [32].
Besides, another nanocomposite Ws-N-Zr, which was developed by our previous study, is also involved here for comparison [33].

Such phenomenon for phosphate enhancement further demonstrate the realization of strong inner-sphere complexation within LaPO4 species and similar results were also observed in our previous study using zirconium phosphate for phosphate capture [35].
